text:
I installed Ant under a directory that contains Japanese characters:
ANT_HOME=F:\sources\compile_environment\テスト２\apache-ant-1.6.3beta1

It won't start:
F:\sources\compile_environment\テスト２>apache-ant-1.6.3beta1\bin\ant.bat
java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: org.apache.tools.ant.Main
        at java.net.URLClassLoader$1.run(URLClassLoader.java:199)
        at java.security.AccessController.doPrivileged(Native Method)
        at java.net.URLClassLoader.findClass(URLClassLoader.java:187)

If I rename the Japanese part into something English and redefine ANT_HOME it
works fine:

F:\sources\compile_environment\test2>set
ANT_HOME=F:\sources\compile_environment\test2\apache-ant-1.6.3beta1

F:\sources\compile_environment\test2>apache-ant-1.6.3beta1\bin\ant.bat
Buildfile: build.xml
...

It happens with both 1.6.2 and 1.6.3beta1.
My OS is Windows 2000 Server Japanese, java version "1.4.2_05" (Java HotSpot(TM)
Server VM (build 1.4.2_FUJITSU_MODIFIED-B10, mixed mode))
creator: dies@jp.fujitsu.com

text:
Just tested this on WinXP SP2, JDK1.5, Japanese character on path of ANT_HOME -
no problems for trunk.

If this is still an issue for you, please upgrade ant to 1.6.5 and retest.

Thanks
creator: kevin.jackson@it.fts-vn.com

text:
Actually, this bug is present in ant 1.6.5 too and has been fixed on Nov 30th,
2005, with changes in Locator.java and other classes. Someone had reported on
the user list that if ANT_HOME is set to c:\änt (a unlaut n t) ant does not start.

Right now the only work around for this bug is to compile oneself a new ant from
the code in SVN.
creator: antoine@apache.org
